description: This course is intended to introduce students to the national institutions and political processes of American government. What are the historical and philosophical foundations of the American Republic? How does American public policy get made, who makes it, and who benefits? Is a constitutional fabric woven in 1787 good enough for today? How, if at all, should American government be changed, and why? What is politics and why bother to study it? If these sorts of questions interest you, then this course will be a congenial home. It is designed to explore such questions while teaching students the basics of American politics and government.
name: INTRO TO AMERICAN POL.

values.comments:
Political Science 130 introduces students to the national institutions and political processes of American government. The course examines questions about public policy, while teaching students the basics of American politics and government.

Numerous students described this course as "essentially a civics class." Many students described the readings for this course as "dry" and "overly complex."  

While students reported that Professor Meredith "really knows his stuff," many disliked his tendency to read straight from his lecture slides. 

Many students felt overwhelmed by the amount of reading for this course. Students who enjoyed this course best were those with some background on the subject. Students would not recommend this course for freshmen.
